PostValue.explanation: Useful, practical resource for people trying to get jobs in the EA/impact sector — can materially improve career decisions, applications, and hiring outcomes for individuals and thus modestly increase effective staffing of impact-focused orgs. Not foundational to EA theory or strategy, and has minimal direct importance for humanity at large beyond small downstream staffing effects.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Unclear scope and guidance for askers — big risk readers will post low-quality or disallowed questions. Actionable fix: add a short ‘How to ask’ section (1–3 bullets) with examples of good vs bad questions, and state clearly what you will and won’t answer (e.g., general hiring timelines, salary ranges, interview prep = OK; feedback on current/past applications or confidential org-specific decisions = NOT OK). This reduces wasted effort and speeds useful answers.

2) Missing recruiter remits / role coverage — readers don’t know which participant to direct role-specific questions to. Actionable fix: include 1-line remit for each participant (e.g., “Calum — recruiting for research & communications roles at GiveWell”; “Phil — senior program hires at Open Phil”) or at minimum which org-levels/teams they typically recruit for. Also note major gaps in representation (most are from GiveWell/Open Phil/CEA) so readers shouldn’t assume coverage across all EA orgs.

3) No guidance on confidentiality, anonymity, or response expectations — this can cause privacy risks and confusion about timing/prioritization. Actionable fix: clarify whether askers can post personally identifying details, whether answers may be quoted or summarized later, and give a simple timeline/triage rule (e.g., “we’ll prioritize upvoted questions and those clearly tagged by topic; expect replies within X days; we’ll stop answering on Aug 1”). If you can’t do some things (e.g., salary disclosure), say so explicitly.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Actionable, concise, and addresses real clarity gaps that will reduce low-value questions and misdirected asks (how to ask, participant remits, confidentiality/response expectations). Some points duplicate existing caveats (timeline, not commenting on active/past apps), so not strictly critical, but adding these items would materially improve usefulness and reduce wasted effort.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: Name too ambiguous to identify a single author. No widely known EA/rationalist figure or globally prominent writer who goes only by 'Calum' is readily identifiable. If you mean a specific person (e.g., Calum Miller, Calum Chace, etc.), provide the full name or links and I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is very clear: it states who is hosting the AMA, lists participants, gives the timeframe (answers by August 1), and provides sensible caveats. It's easy to understand and concise. Minor improvements could include explicit instructions on how to submit questions (e.g., reply in-thread), expected response cadence, or a brief note on confidentiality/conflicts of interest, which would raise it to a perfect 10.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is an AMA — a common format on the EA Forum — offering recruiting/advice from staff at EA-focused orgs. While the specific roster (GiveWell, Open Phil, Charity Entrepreneurship, CEA) is of interest to the community, the concept and content (job/recruiting Q&A) are routine and unsurprising for EA readers. For the general public it's slightly less familiar but still a common, low-novelty informational event.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This is primarily an informational/announcement post rather than an argumentative piece. The claim — that a group of recruiters will answer questions — is clear, simple, and well-scoped. The post provides relevant supporting evidence (named participants, roles, and LinkedIn links) and sensible caveats about limits to their responses. There is little need for deeper logical argumentation or empirical evidence; the only minor gaps are lack of precise availability/schedule details and the inherently self-reported nature of credentials.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: The post’s main empirical claims (the AMA exists, its Jul 22, 2025 posting and the stated list of participants) are directly verifiable. The Effective Altruism Forum post is real and dated Jul 22, 2025 and the named participants are listed there. Organization team pages corroborate the participants’ affiliations/titles at the time of checking. Minor caveats: small wording differences in job titles across sources (e.g., “Recruiting Lead” vs “Interim Recruiting Manager”) and the usual temporal risk that people’s roles change after the post date. All checks were performed against the organizations’ public team pages and the forum thread on 2025-08-27.
